here is the what\'s new content
Unknown commands, when a command is not recognised
control certain features of Saiy. These features include the recording of audio, passing of this speech data to the remote application and varying the type of voice engine used.
Read and announce notification content. Interact with user input parameters.
Please enable the Say accessibility service to use this feature.
Text-to-Speech Gender: preferred gender when available
Currently, no installed applications can communicate with Saiy
A link to the settings section, full of tweaks and application defaults.
A link to the advanced settings section, full of more technical tweaks and application defaults.
A link to the troubleshooting and bugs section, where you can look for solutions to any problems you might be having.
A link to the customisation section, full of fun ways you can make me your own.
Would you like to start the Voice Tutorial?
A user guide, that will teach you in more detail how elements of the application work.
Not compatible with your Unknown Command selection

Should you wish, you can select here whether I use offline voice recognition by default, even when an active network connection is available. Do be aware, the offline recognition is far less accurate than its network equivalent, so you\'ll need to be prepared for more unknown command responses than normal. Additionally, even if you have successfully installed the offline recognition files, it may take a number of device reboots before Google correctly detects them. More information on this issue can be found in the Troubleshooting and Bugs section.

This feature is experimental, and uses an offline recognition engine, separate to Google\'s. In testing, it was often necessary for the wake up phrases to be repeated more than once in order to be detected. This was especially prevalent with a high level of background ambient noise. These issues are being worked on and will no doubt be resolved soon. Whilst this feature doesn\'t require an active network connection, you should be aware that it cannot make use of the dedicated CPU cores that some devices are equipped with. Consequently, it will consume a considerably greater amount of battery power, compared to Google\'s own, okay, implementation. Which as a system application, is able to make use of this. When the hotword detection is active, an intrusive notification will be placed in the status bar. This is to ensure you don\'t accidentally leave the feature enabled, and kill your battery.

If your text to speech engine supports it, this setting allows you to configure whether I should speak in a male or female voice by default. I will attempt to apply this setting when pronouncing translations for you. Which can sound a little silly when I suddenly change from an English lady, to a German man. Only at the weekends. Ahem.
Select voice account: an account to associate
%1$s already has a vocal association with Saiy. Would you like to unlink the current association and start a new one?

When working correctly, this option allows you to shorten or extend the amount of time you are given, before the voice recognition assumes you have completed your input. Unfortunately, Google have been ignoring these parameters for a long time, which means you are going to need to compose long emails and text messages without taking a breath. You will also need to begin speaking immediately after the recognition beep. I really hope Google fixes these issues soon, so we can all breathe a sigh of relief, without the recognition timing out.

Here you can select whether I use device vibration at different points throughout the application. Please be aware, some vibrations are generated by the Android system, or Google voice recognition, and cannot be prevented.
A link to the development section, where you can get involved with making me even smarter.
This will reset all settings to default, as if you\'d just installed Saiy.\n\nThis includes all customisations, tweaks and commands.

This will allow me to respond to all commands, even when the device is locked.\n\nPlease consider carefully whether you should enable this feature, as I will respond to all requests from any voice instruction to read and send messages, call contacts, announce your agenda - and much more.

In a future release, here you\'ll be able to tweak the thresholds of the algorithms I use to compare spoken words, to close alternatives. Increasing them too much will result in many false positives, but finding the right balance may help me to detect your commands, even if Google is sending back something completely different. At present, the legacy option only applies to contact matching.

External applications installed on your device, can request that I speak on their behalf, or register keyphrases that perform actions specific to their content. Any such application will need to request permission from you to do so. If you find that one is abusing the privilege, you can blacklist it here, and prevent it from connecting to me.

Due to a bug in Google\'s hotword detection service, where they are hogging the microphone and not sharing. I may just keep beeping multiple times when you try to activate me. Enabling this option will allow me to identify when this is occurring, and murder Google\'s Assistant. With pleasure.

Certain Android devices don\'t like the way I attempt to enable the flashlight. Toggle this setting if you are having problems. My developer is aware of an issue that causes the torch to disable when the display turns off. He\'s working on it.
If you require a stand alone application to launch me in listening mode. Perhaps for your car unit, or a button mapping app. Then this is the option for you.

To function, I need to bind to both a text to speech, and a voice recognition engine. The combination of my own memory usage, as well as theirs, will show in the Android running process list, as a collective total. This level may alarm some users, and lead them to incorrectly believe the memory allocation is proportional to my battery consumption. This is an incorrect assumption. Regardless, here you can set how quickly I release my binding to both engines. Before you consider reducing this time span, please do read further in the Troubleshooting and Bugs section.

If your preferred note provider is not appearing as a choice, then this is the place for you. There are many ways different note apps expect to receive the content and title, and here I do my best to provide you with as many options as possible to make your favourite app work correctly. Select an option and then press test. If the note app you want appears as a choice, then select them and check the test content and title are populated correctly. If you exhaust all of the options, then it may be that the app you want, simply isn\'t handling the request correctly. Drop my developer a quick email from the Development Section, and he\'ll do his best to give them a nudge.
Due to a bug in Google\'s hotword detection service, your okay Google command might not be functioning correctly. Enabling this option should work around this problem for now.
This setting allows you to override what I consider to be a secure function, and perform it even when the device is locked. This is not recommended. Tap for a detailed explanation.

Prior to speaking, initiating the voice recognition, or performing a command that requires a network connection, I check the network speed by using a ping test. If for some reason, this is negatively affecting how I perform, you can disable it here.
Due to a bug in Google\'s recognition service, you might be plagued by an error that says the service is busy. Enabling this option should provide a temporary fix.
If something has happened that is causing me to misbehave, you can reset me to a default installation state here.
If you\'d like to clear the default options in Android, that Saiy responds to, such as a headset button press, clicking here will remove all defaults set.
When enabled in a coming release, you\'ll be able to customise commands that require root or system access to process.
You can toggle this setting to decide whether or not I am automatically started by the Android System
For some users, dictated message content fails to appear in their default messaging application. Toggling this setting should fix the issue.
For a small number of users, requesting text message content from a specific contact will fail. Toggling this setting will hopefully resolve this issue.
This is an experimental feature. Tap for a detailed explanation.

If the voice action button on your wired headset is not doing anything, or not defaulting to me, when your screen is off, you can use this fix to set things up correctly. When you tap on this option, if I\'m activated successfully, then all is good. If it starts another application, then you\'ll need to locate that app in the Android Application Settings, and click on. Clear defaults. Before returning here to try again. You\'ll most likely get shown a dialog to choose between the various Assistants on your device. I would highly recommend you choose me. For obvious reasons.
location set by GPS, input method
The input cannot contain special characters

Due to the manufacturer of your device altering the location of certain settings, you\'ll need to manually find the setting that will grant me, the %1$s permission. If you have any trouble finding it, I\'m sure Google will be your friend.
draw over other apps, or System overlays
If I can\'t record audio, I won\'t be able to hear you!
So I can float the command window anywhere on the device, including over the top of other applications, I need the permission for system overlays.
To \'float\' the command list anywhere on the device, I require this permission.
A list of inbuilt structured commands that I obey
A voice tutorial that will guide you through the basics of the application.
Welcome to the first release of me. Say. To stop this tutorial, you can tap the notification in the status bar at any time. Otherwise, sit back, relax and let\'s take a look around.
First place we\'ll go is the command list where the in-built structured commands are detailed. I\'m going to give you thirty seconds to memorise them all, and then we\'ll start the test. Go.

Just kidding. There\'s a lot to take in here, but don\'t worry, you don\'t have to memorise every one to use the application, as each command below can be changed to your liking in the Customisation section. You can float this command list any time you need a reminder of what to say. You can do this by simply saying, float commands, and this box will appear.

You can tap on each command for an explanation and example usage, and it can be resized and moved around the screen, so it doesn\'t get in the way too much. Okay, let\'s try a command or two and I\'ll show you what Google voice recognition is sending back for me to work with. To activate me from anywhere on the device, simply tap the notification in the status bar, and start speaking when the device beeps or vibrates

shortly afterwards a listening notification will appear in the status bar. Starting to speak too soon is a common reason users get poor results. Google gives you very little time after the beep to begin speaking, so you\'ll need to be prompt to avoid an error. I hope they\'ll fix this issue soon. Right, let\'s get on with it. Just a final few things to remember. Please speak to me in a perfectly natural way, just as if you were chatting to a friend. Don\'t speak louder than normal, or attempt to over annunciate your words. The recognition will be much more accurate this way, and also improve much quicker with your usage. Okay, here we go. Please repeat after me.
Google doesn\'t give you much time to speak after the beep, so you\'ll need to be fairly prompt. Let\'s try that again. After the beep, say
Excellent. Google Voice recognition returned that nice and clearly in the voice data. Let\'s try another. Repeat after me.
Well that didn\'t go too well, as it\'s not appeared in the list of returned voice recognition results. We won\'t panic just yet, let\'s try something else. Repeat after me.
Say, one two three four five
Great. I was able to confirm your speech input from the Google voice recognition results, although it wasn\'t entirely accurate.
Google is too quick to detect silence, if you don\'t speak right after the beep. It\'s frustrating, but let\'s try again. After the beep, say
Excellent. Google returned that as the highest suggested result, this is going well. Let\'s get to know each other a little better.
Okay, not great, as Google didn\'t return your intended input within the results at all. We won\'t worry just yet though. Let\'s get to know each other a little better.
Tell me, are you a boy or a girl?
Google Voice recognition returned an error. Don\'t forget to speak promptly after the beep. Let\'s try that again.
Great. I was able to piece together your speech input from the Google voice recognition results, although the accuracy was a little low. Let\'s get to know each other a little better.
Great, men are so much more predictable.
Great, girls are much more intelligent.

Next, I\'m going to ask you to tell me your name. You can change how I address you when you activate me by saying the command, call me, followed by your name. So, I would say, call me. Say. After the beep, try this command.
Well I\'m sure that has many advantages.
I didn\'t detect your answer in the results. Never mind, let\'s try again. After the beep
say, call me, followed by your name.
I still didn\'t detect your answer in the results. Never mind, let\'s move on.
I heard your name as, %1$s. Is that correct?
That\'s the most unusual name. Are you quite certain you want me to address you as, %1$s?
I didn\'t detect your name in the voice results. Not to worry, let\'s try again. After the beep, say the command, call me, followed by your name
I still didn\'t detect your name in the results. Never mind, you can manually enter this later in the Customisation Section. Let\'s go there now.
Google didn\'t detect any speech. Remember to speak straight after that beep.
Great. It\'s a pleasure to meet you %1$s. Okay, let\'s head over to the customisation section, where the fun really starts.
Oh dear. Never mind, let\'s try once more. After the beep, please say the command, call me, followed by your name.

Okay. Google Voice Recognition often has trouble detecting names. We\'ll move on for now, but you can manually enter your phonetic name at any time in the Customisation Section. Let\'s head there now and have a look around.
Let\'s try once more. After the beep, please say the command, call me, followed by your name.
There was a problem with the voice recognition. Don\'t forget to speak right after that beep!
Google voice recognition returned an error, as it detected silence. Please do speak immediately after the beep. I know it\'s annoying.

If you scroll up and down you\'ll see all the fun you\'re about to have, tweaking the things I can do and say. You can create entire conversations and baffle your friends with exactly how much I appear to know, about the most random of subjects. You can make me giggle [giggle] cough [cough] or make any other sound effect you download and place on your device storage.
You can long press each of the menu items, and I\'ll explain in detail how the features work. Right, let\'s go to the settings section.

There are plenty of tweaks here to keep you busy, from ways you can activate me, to the voice I\'ll speak with when responding to your commands. Most important are the unknown command options, which will let me know what to do when I don\'t understand your voice input. The default setting is to inform you that I didn\'t know what you meant, but this can be easily changed, to ask Google to perform a web search, or simply ask you to repeat the question. There are many other possible options, depending on the supported applications you have installed on your device.

The same as the customisation section, you can long press on each item, so I can explain the usage further. You\'ll notice that some of the features are marked, coming soon. Sorry to disappoint, they will be available as soon as my developer gets his ass into gear. Next, let\'s go to the Supported Applications section.

Here you\'ll see the applications that I am currently compatible with, or will be within the next couple of releases. For security reasons, you\'ll need to manually authorise some of the applications here. If you are a more advanced user, I can execute any of your Tasker tasks for you.

Details of how to use the Tasker plug in can be found in the user guide, which also contains a sample project. The user guide has many sections, from basic usage, to sound effects, and the most common solutions to bugs. Please do take the time to read the links if you are having a problem.

Finally, the development section. As I am now an open source project, the input of users, such as yourself, will assist me to get very smart, very quickly. If each user made just a single contribution here, I will be destroying the human race before you can say singularity. Until that point, you could contribute to my code base, help translate me to your native language, submit your ideas of how to improve me, perhaps your frustrations with how I function, or maybe just some general feedback, where you tell my developer how handsome you think he is. Despite my facial recognition algorithms begging to differ.
Okay. I think I\'ve waffled enough.

Please remember that you can long press on any menu item, and I\'ll be here to explain in detail how you can use each feature. I hope we are going to have some fun together, and you\'ll find me super useful. Speak soon.

We had a little trouble during this tutorial, but don\'t worry, Google\'s voice recognition is backed by machine learning, so it will improve with every usage. There are also many features in the Customisation Section designed to help me to understand you better.

Google Voice Recognition is not behaving. I apologise on their behalf. You can have a read in the Troubleshooting and Bugs section for ways you maybe able to resolve this. I\'m afraid I\'ll have to end the tutorial here, before you no doubt get more frustrated than I am.
Apologies, but something has gone wrong with the tutorial and I\'m unable to recover from the error. Please feel free to report this in the Development Section.
You need an active network connection
Your volume may be too low!
• Read my last text message from +\'contact name\'

My developer has aged considerably, whilst attempting to get headsets to work correctly. The behaviour of each varies exponentially depending on the following:

• Headset manufacturer
• Headset protocol
• Android device manufacturer
• Android version
• Text to Speech engine

The next dialog will provide you with a vast number of options, that can independently be changed in order to cover as manually eventualities as possible.

Finding the right combination that works best for you, may take a little trial and error. Please do attempt each combination a few times, as often there can be a delay applying the chosen configuration. You'll need to press 'Save' after each change you make.

If weird and wonderful things start happening, disconnecting and reconnecting your headset should resolve the newly created problem!

Whilst testing different configurations, you will notice the following behavioural changes, for better or for worse…

• TTS audio output
• Audio output quality
• Audio input quality
• Audio prompts (beeps)

Hopefully you will find the configuration combination that accomplishes all! If you don't, please feel free to send my developer an email containing your headset details. They are his favourite kind!

Note: Google settled for the low quality audio option for their Assistant…

Whether or not the voice recognition and text to speech engine appear to behave correctly on your device, you can run a quick diagnostics check here. Once it has completed, it may provide some suggested improvements to help things function even better. My developer had fun making this feature, mainly because he is a massive geek.
Currently, only the Google Text-to-Speech engine supports this feature correctly.\n\nYou\'ll need to install the engine from the Play Store to use this feature.
You need to install Google Now from the Play Store
You need to install a text to speech engine from the Play Store. It\'s recommended to install Google Text to Speech
It\'s recommended to install the Google Text to Speech from the Play Store
No need to make any changes
Please install a supported Text-to-Speech language
Google Voice Recognition did not return any supported languages due to a known bug
Out of your installed Text-to-Speech engines, only Google currently supports this feature correctly.\n\nPlease switch your default engine to Google to use this feature.
It\'s recommended to set your default text to speech engine to Google Text to Speech
You need to set your Voice Recognition Provider to Google in the Android Settings
Your default voice engine is reporting that it does not have an installed supported language. Please see if you are able to install one from the Android Text to Speech Settings.
Alternatively, switch your default voice engine to Google Text to Speech, which fully supports all features.
Alternatively, install the recommended Google Text to Speech Engine from the Play Store, which fully supports all features.
Your default voice engine failed the speech test. You can try uninstalling and reinstalling the engine and any associated language packs you have installed.

Google Text to Speech engine failed the speech test. This is unfortunate, as it is usually the most reliable amongst its alternatives. However, it can take a long time to initialise on some devices, under low memory conditions, so a fresh reboot of your device may solve the issue in the short term. Alternatively, try uninstalling and reinstalling the engine and any associated language packs you have installed. If it continues to fail, you may need to switch to a lower quality, unsupported voice engine, such a Pico TTS
Testing speech with a 15 second timeout

Many Text to Speech Engines don\'t support switching between genders and languages, or don\'t support it correctly…\n\nI would recommend running the diagnostics check before selecting a voice, to check if your current default voice engine will behave when attempting this!
\n\nRegardless, it\'s a good idea to run the diagnostics to check everything else is working correctly with your current default voice engine.
\n\nWhy not check in your Android About Settings to see if an update is available?
Your device doesn\'t support this feature as it was only introduced in Android 5.0 Lollipop ☹

In the current release, only English is supported. But don\'t fear, translationProvider to all languages supported by Google Voice Recognition is underway! Head to the development section if you\'d like to assist translating me to your native language.
If your device and text to speech engine supports it, you can select the voice I will speak in here.

Rather than me simply announcing when I don\'t understand your voice input, you can select alternative options here. You could select passing unknown commands to the Google Assistant. That way, you can deliberately ask me something I won\'t understand, and Google will take over. Click to check out the other options.
Click here for more headset options, than there are atoms in the Universe.

If you\'d like me to speak at a fixed level above or below your media stream, then you can apply this setting here. Unfortunately it\'s not working correctly on some Android versions, but my developer is on the case of that. There are two other options. One to show a toast when I believe my text to speech output might be set too low, and another to set which volume streams I check. On some Android devices, the global device volume profile overrides your media stream. On others, it doesn\'t. If I seem to be reporting incorrectly that your volume is too low, try un-ticking the, assume global volume, option.
If you\'d like to show or remove the shortcut button on the permanent notification to directly speak to Alexa, you can do so by tapping here.
If you\'d like to place a shortcut on your launcher that activates me, you can do so by tapping here.

If your default voice engine is Google, you can decide whether to use a higher quality network synthesised voice. When your device network connection is slow, this may cause considerable lag when waiting for me to speak. There\'s an option you can select to only synthesise when you\'re connected to WiFi.
You can select your default temperature units to apply here. They\'ll be used across the application whenever applicable.

Amazon automatically creates an 'Alexa Profile' associated with your account, even if you don't yet own any hardware.

If you do, then great! Saiy will connect with your existing Alexa service, including any linked smart home devices you have and allow you to control their features. Otherwise, as a new user, your commands will be a little more restricted.

Please do consider installing the Alexa Companion App if it is available in your region, to enhance your experience and manage your 'skills'.

For now, here are some example usages:

• What's the longest river in the world?
• How old is Tom Hanks?
• How's the weather looking?
• Give me a recipe for chicken pot pie
• Are you better than Saiy?
• Reorder coffee
• Turn on the bedroom lights

Have fun!
Button for authorization through Login with Amazon
To enable me to post your dictated content to Facebook, you can authorise my access here.
Tap here to install %1$s from the Play Store
So I can automatically tweet your dictated content, you can authorise my access to your Twitter feed here.
To enable me to connect to Alexa, you\'ll need to manually authorise access via your Amazon account. Please note. This does not grant me any other permissions for your account itself.
To automatically run your Tasker tasks for you, tap here to make sure our applications can communicate correctly.
In a future release, you\'ll be able to dictate content you\'d like me to automatically post to Linked In.
To access nearby places that you may wish to check in to, using Foursquare, I\'ll need your authorisation here.

Due to an annoying Android bug, Tasker hasn\'t detected that I hold the permission to remotely run tasks for you. In order to fix this issue, I need to reinstall myself, so the Android system correctly detects the permission.

To do this, you need to briefly enable the option to allow installations from Unknown Sources. This setting prevents installation from anywhere other than the Play Store, which is a good idea, but it also prevents me from reinstalling myself from the current version already stored on your device. If you tick the box to allow Unknown Sources and return to the application, I\'ll guide you further from there.
Great. Please tap the button to reinstall me and I\'ll be back shortly.
That felt very strange. I wonder I remain the same entity as I was before? Regardless,
Tasker should be correctly configured now
Don\'t forget to change the setting back to block external installations. It\'ll keep your device safe.
Tap on the install button and I\'ll be back shortly.

If you would like any credits you earn to persist across multiple devices, or in a future release, be able to redeem them, you will need to identify yourself using one of a number of familiar login procedures.\n\nIt\'s pretty painless and only takes a few clicks!
Are you sure you want to delete your account?\n\nThis will remove all history of any credits you have earned to date.
Account is disabled by the administrator

Saiy will be translated into every language that is supported by a voice recognition provider, but as you can imagine, this is going to be a mammoth task!

I'll need the help of our community of users to achieve this and we're going to attempt it using the Crowdin Platform.

If you want to get involved and translate the odd word or sentence every now and then over a coffee (no pressure!) click the sign up link below to create an account! It's free and easy!

Thanks in advance!
If you\'d like to help translate me into your native language, this is the place to get started.

Please describe the problem you are experiencing and how to replicate it, if possible.\n\nClicking on email below, will prepopulate some of your device data into the body of the message. Hopefully this will make the bug easier to resolve!
If you\'ve found I\'m suffering from a bug, you can submit it to my developer here.

In no particular order:

• Customisable hotword
• Wired headsets
• Bluetooth headsets
• Car kits
• Wear compatibility
• Multiple intro support
• Google Assistant vs browser choice
• Hotword screen off
• Full application back-up
• Location aware profiles
• User sound effects
• Save emotion analysis
• Regex in commands
• MicroG support

Commands:

• Heart rate
• Steps
• Stopwatch
• Run
• Workout
• Bike ride
• ICE
• Music search
• Agenda timespans
• Delete alarms
• 24 hour time
• etc…!
View a list of what my developer is working on in the very near future. Once he has completed this list, he has my permission to get a life.

In order to improve your experience and that of others, I collect anonymous usage data whilst you are interacting with me. Such information may contain the particular command you attempted, how it was requested, and if it resulted in a success or failure. This will help me to identify any potential errors negative to my performance, and report them to my developer. In addition, the time you spend in various parts of the application may be logged. Which again, will never be individually identifiable to you.
An email link for commercial enquiries.
If you are the developer of another application and would like to know how your app can take advantage of communicating with me, click here.
Click to visit the website of my icon designer. He\'s very talented.

XDA Developers is my birthplace. Without the support of the community there, my developer would never have got this far. There are too many members to list individually, but some stand-out contributors are thanked here. Tap for legends.
Tap to view the open source license agreements.
Click to view the application\'s privacy policy
Click to view the release notes of the current version.
Tap here to go to my website.
If you speak German, tap here to visit the blog of a dedicated tester of mine.
Should you like to see how I\'ve been created in Java, tap here to view my source code.
Click to read the application\'s terms of use

UPDATE!\n\nThe way in which I announce notifications has changed and therefore, if you only have my Accessibility Service enabled for this reason, you can now disable it to save some battery.
You\'ve received a new text message from
You\'ve received a new text message
Without this permission I cannot function. You can grant this by clicking the Permissions button below

I require the, microphone, permission to record your voice and understand what you are saying. Without this permission, I\'m afraid I\'ll be useless\! You can grant this by clicking the Permissions button below
I require the, files, permission, in order to access sounds effects that are placed on your device storage, as well as import and export your custom commands.

I require the, accounts and contacts, permission to do many things. To associate your voice with a specific account. To assist you with making and receiving calls. To help you send text messages and announce their content. Sending emails, your social media obligations, and much more.
I require the, accounts and contacts, permission to use this feature. You can manually allow this in the Application Settings, under permissions.
I require the, telephony and call log, permissions to do many things. To assist you with making and receiving calls. To announce who is calling you or who you may have missed a call from.
I require the, location, permissions to do many things. To assist you with navigation and appointment commands, determine locations for your car or bike, or even just you, if you are ever lost.
I require the, calendar, permissions in order to check your agenda, navigate to appointments, announce their content and attendees.
I require the, read SMS, permission in order to access your message inbox, and therefore be able to inform you who has messaged, and what they said.

I require the, send SMS, permission to enable me to send text messages on your behalf, without your physical interaction. When you are driving for example, or have your hands full with something else. I\'ll always double check the recipient and content with you prior to doing this, and it will of course, only ever be as a result of your direct instruction.
So I can access the number of your incoming calls, and search for the associated contact. I require the permission to read the phone state.
You\'ll need to manually grant me notification access permissions to use this feature.

Use this feature to set a global quiet time, so I can identify if it is too early or too late to make you aware of content I would normally announce. I wouldn\'t want to disturb your beauty sleep now, would I.

Here you can set your date of birth, so I can automatically fetch the corresponding astrological reading for you. Details of how you should interpret your horoscope, and help it guide you through your daily life, can be found in the, doesn\'t exist, section.

For some users, my ability to accurately detect the correct contact, is flawless, even if Google failed to return the precise name in the voice data. For those who are fortunate enough to experience this, the requirement to confirm the contact each time may become an annoyance, and therefore you have the option here to turn off the confirmation. Disable at your own risk though. As it would be just typical, that I\'d end up incorrectly calling an ex partner of yours, to whom you\'d really rather not explain, that your virtual assistant did it by accident. Honest.

Here you can allow me to announce notifications received by your device, and in some cases, whether or not I should include the content. Many notifications contain content that I am unable to access, or occur very frequently. You can prevent me from announcing these notifications by excluding specific application packages, keywords or keyphrases. Some Android devices, frequently display a location notification, stating, location set by GPS. This is automatically ignored for you. You can add as many exclusion keyphrases as you like, separated by a comma.

Whilst I do my best to correctly punctuate the voice data I receive, it is often missing the basics, and consequently, so will any message content you dictate. Allowing the recipient to know it was composed by voice, by including a signature, may prevent them from assuming you rarely attended English class at school. You can customise the signature content here, and decide whether or not to include my developer\'s shameless plug.
So I am able to reduce your ringtone volume, when you receive an incoming call, I require the, do not disturb, permission here.

If you\'d like me to announce incoming calls and give you the option to answer or decline them, then this is the option for you. Do be aware, some Android versions don\'t play well with this function, especially when you request I answer the call on loudspeaker. I\'m sure my developer will solve this problem soon.

You need to manually authorise my access to your Amazon account to use this feature. You\'re not required to own any Alexa hardware, as I can connect remotely to the default Alexa service associated with your account. Otherwise, if you\'d like to remove the button from the notification, you can do so in the settings.
You need to manually authorise my access to your Amazon account to use this feature.
would you like to answer it?
"No application is installed to handle this request?"
"I didn't receive any voice data from the recognition provider."
"I didn't receive any voice data. This could be due to the profanity filter set by your voice recognition provider."
"I don't know what I'm supposed to be doing."
Do you need to install offline language files?

You may be suffering from a bug associated with Google\'s voice recognition service, where their assistant is not playing nicely and won\'t share the microphone with me. I hope they\'ll fix this issue soon, but in the mean time, you\'ll need to force stop the application to get things working again.
Not working correctly on many Android versions!
"There is a problem with your Text to Speech engine."
"There was a problem with the Text to Speech playback."
"In order for the application to function, you need to have a voice recognition provider installed. Please install the Google Now application from the Play Store."

"In order for the application to speak, you need to install a Text to Speech engine. Please select one from the list below and then set it as your default in the Android Text to Speech Settings, which can be found under the Language and Input section"

"I was unable to speak in the requested language. This could be a simple solution, such as an additional download of the language files, which you can do from the settings within your voice engine. Click on the link below to go there."

"Unfortunately, Samsung do not allow their Vlingo voice recognition to be used by any other applications, than S Voice. Please change the default provider to Google. Click the button below to go to the Settings."

"Unfortunately, your device is suffering from a known Android bug, where I am unable to open the Usage Statistics Settings in order for you to grant me permission to access them. This will cause a number of problems with commands associated with application usage. Please check for an update to your Android version in your device settings, as your manufacturer may have already pushed a fix to resolve this."

This feature is only available if you are using Google Voice Recognition.

You'll need to make sure you have correctly downloaded and installed the offline recognition files from the Android Voice Search Settings.

It is often necessary to reboot your device once you have done this.

Click to go to the Settings.

First thing to check is your media volume. On some devices it may not be obvious that this stream alone is set too low or muted.

A more likely problem is your voice engine is in error; this happens all too often… In the Android Text to Speech Settings double check any additional download files are installed and up to date. There's an option to 'listen to a sample' which you can test too.

It's highly recommended to use the Google text to speech engine as at the time of writing, despite taking a little longer to initially warm up, it is the only one that seems to work at least relatively reliably…

If all else fails, try rebooting your device, as this can sometimes fix weird and wonderful problems for no apparent reason at all…

Tap for Text to Speech Settings. Tap and hold for Volume Settings

Text to speech engines take up a lot of resource and consequently can take a while to initialise and be ready to speak. This is more common on higher quality engines, regardless of whether they are downloaded and installed on the device or not.

In the Superuser Settings, under Memory Usage, you can adjust how long the text to speech engine is bound to Saiy and kept in the memory. The longer allowed time, the less likely the initialisation process will be required for subsequent commands

This additional memory usage should be negligible to the performance of any modern device. If Android needs the memory back, it will take it!

In the Saiy Settings, if you have selected to use the network synthesised voices (available via Google's text to speech engine), a delay can occur due to the speed of your network connection. If your mobile connectivity is a little hit and miss, disabling this feature unless you are connected to WiFi, could certainly help…

Tap for settings. Tap and hold for Superuser Settings

So I can automatically toggle the hotword recognition when you open certain applications, that may stream media content, or need access to the microphone, I require the statistics permission here. I\'ll then be able to check which apps you are using, and act accordingly.
"I need to capture approximately fifteen seconds of audio, so please count quickly up to forty. That should be sufficient."
"The vocal verification process succeeded. I'll now be able to identify you, before providing sensitive information, or on request"

"You need to create an account to associate your voice to."
"I don't have a complete voice footprint associated with your account. You'll need to create another one."
"Thank you. I'll notify you shortly when I've finished analysing the audio"
"Okay. I'll notify you when I've analysed the audio."
"You need to install the Tasker application to use this command."
"You don't appear to have any tasks to execute"
"So I can execute tasks for you, please tick the box that allows external access"

"There was an error communicating with Tasker. This is a known Android bug where the Tasker permissions are not detected, if you installed Tasker after me. You'll need to reinstall me, so the permissions are correctly applied. Click on the re-assimilate button"
"Sorry %1$s, but there was a problem opening the %2$s application"
"The application, %1$s, is no longer installed. Please select or install another one."
"Please select or install the supported application you would like to handle this command."
"I'm afraid %1$s, that translations are currently limited to 2000 characters."
"Sorry %1$s, but there was a problem completing that translationProvider."
"I'm sorry %1$s, but that language is not currently supported for translations"
"I successfully processed a request from the application, %1$s."
"A request from the application, %1$s, has failed."
"A request from a remote application has failed. The remote application did not identify itself. You can delete which applications are allowed to send me command requests from my Settings."
The application, %1$s, failed to successfully register a command.
The application, %1$s, successfully registered the command, %2$s
"Sorry %1$s, there was a problem accessing your battery information."
"Sorry %1$s, I'm not sure what specific battery information you required."
"OK %1$s. Don't forget you need to speak for at least thirteen seconds."

"OK %1$s. In order for me to analyse your emotional state, you need to speak for at least thirteen seconds. After that, I'll detect when you've finished speaking. You could tell me about your day today, or about a memory from your past. If you can't think of anything, just close your eyes and count slowly up to fifteen, whilst your mind wanders. I'll let you know with a notification when the analysis is complete."
Alexa\'s media requests make little sense I\'m afraid.
Alexa just asked me to set the volume to, %1$s. I\'m not sure how to go about doing that.
Sorry, but due to Amazon\'s strict encryption requirements, this feature is only available on devices running Marshmallow or higher.
When I haven\'t understood a command, this option allows me to show you a toast of the speech content returned by Google. It\'s a little selfish really, as I want you to blame them, and not me!
Your current driving profile configuration requires some additional permissions. Click on the option below, and once you\'ve made your selection, press save. And I will guide you from there.

This feature allows you to configure my behaviour when I detect that you are driving. Under these conditions, you may wish that I behave in a more verbose manner than normal. Such as announcing the identity of incoming callers, or automatically reading your message content. Many more options will be added to the driving profile in future releases. In the mean time, please do stay safe, and don\'t use your device whilst driving.
To get your astrological information, I need to know your date of birth

Please be aware, contacts stored on your SIM card won\'t be detected. If you still have any saved there, it might be a good time to do some housekeeping. Most decent contact applications have an import, export wizard, to make the process nice and easy.

Please see the structured command list to understand what I can do, and how you can get me to do it. If you have a problem, please see the troubleshooting and bugs section in the main application. If you\'re still stuck, do feel free to email the developer or check out the community forum
